required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Will Erectile Dysfunction Increase the Risk of Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Erectile Dysfunction and the Future Risk of Prostate Cancer: a Population-based Longitudinal Follow-up Study With Concurrent Double Comparison Cohorts

brief_summary.textblock: The rationale for investigating the hypothesis that there is an association between erectile dysfunction (ED) and the subsequent development of prostate cancer is based on three assumptions: 1) baseline ED is common in most if not all of the cross-sectional studies in men with prostate cancer; 2) the development of ED and prostate cancer may have certain shared common risk factors; and 3) the use of testosterone for the treatment of ED has been suspected to be associated with prostate cancer development. Controversy exists over whether men with ED have an increased risk of subsequent prostate cancer. Few studies have evaluated the risk of developing prostate cancer for men with ED. The investigators, therefore, conducted a population-based longitudinal study with eight years' follow-up to examine this association and to evaluate the magnitude of the risk.

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, up to 7 years

arm_group.description: Group contains men with physician-diagnosed erectile dysfunction
Men 50 years and older having no ED and pre-existing prostate cancer
Men 50 years old older with symptomatic prostatic hypertrophy but with no ED nor pre-existing prostate cancer

intervention.description: Patients with ED are considered belonging to the exposure group.

study_pop.textblock: The study cohort was constructed from the Taiwan National Health Insurance Research Dataset. From among men with no pre-existing prostate cancer, we formed an ED group of men â‰¥50 years of age and a non-ED general population comparison group of men matched 1:4 by age and index date of the ED group and a concurrent second comparison group of men older than 50 with benign prostatic hypertrophy.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- men 50 years and older with no pre-existing prostate cancer
Exclusion Criteria:
- less than 50 years old
- pre-existing prostate cancer

overall_official.affiliation: Disease Informatics Research Unit, Asia University Taiwan
